title: Achalasia
diagnosis_topic: Failure of lower esophageal sphincter relaxation and absence of peristalsis
setup_script: "A 45-year-old woman presents with progressive difficulty swallowing both solids and liquids over several months. She reports regurgitation of undigested food and has developed a nocturnal cough. She has lost 10 pounds over this time. How would you proceed with this patient?"

dynamic_flow.reply: "She describes dysphagia to solids and liquids, regurgitation of saliva and undigested food, 10-pound weight loss, and denies heartburn."
"Barium swallow shows a markedly dilated esophagus with bird-beak narrowing at the gastroesophageal junction and delayed emptying."
"Manometry demonstrates elevated LES pressure with incomplete relaxation and absent peristalsis."
"Endoscopy rules out malignancy; no obstructing lesion identified."
"Therapeutic options include pneumatic dilation, laparoscopic Heller myotomy with fundoplication, POEM (peroral endoscopic myotomy), or botulinum toxin injection."
"This patient is considered a good candidate for laparoscopic Heller myotomy with Dor fundoplication. What are the key technical steps you would describe?"

"Ports are placed laparoscopically, the esophagus is mobilized, and a 6-cm myotomy on the esophagus with a 2-cm extension onto the stomach is performed. A Dor fundoplication is used for reflux prevention."

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident mentions intraoperative mucosal perforation
dynamic_flow.reply: "How would you manage an intraoperative esophageal mucosal perforation?"
"Small mucosal tears are repaired primarily and the myotomy is extended to ensure adequate relief. A wrap is still performed."

dynamic_flow.trigger: If patient is high surgical risk
dynamic_flow.reply: "For high-risk patients, botulinum toxin injection or pneumatic dilation may be performed but carry higher recurrence risk."
"Without intervention, the esophagus progressively dilates, symptoms worsen, and risk of aspiration pneumonia increases."
"Postoperatively, the patient is started on clear liquids, diet advanced as tolerated, and monitored for GERD symptoms. Proton pump inhibitors are prescribed as needed."
"Follow-up includes monitoring symptoms, periodic imaging or manometry if indicated, and addressing recurrent dysphagia with repeat intervention."
"The patient is advised to eat small frequent meals, elevate the head of bed, and avoid lying flat after eating."

critical_decision_points: Recognition of achalasia and differentiation from pseudoachalasia
Use of appropriate diagnostic tests (barium swallow, manometry, endoscopy)
Selection of definitive therapy based on age and comorbidities
Technical description of Heller myotomy and fundoplication
Recognition and management of intraoperative complications (e.g., mucosal perforation)
Postoperative reflux management and surveillance for recurrence
Patient education on lifestyle modifications and long-term follow-up
